title: QIC boss proposes flexible super contribution rates
text:
Mr Frawley urged the government to "think a bit creatively" about the retirement income system, which is being reviewed by an independent panel.

He suggested "slicing and dicing" the system, acknowledging that there were some employers and employees who might be able to afford to increase their super contribution to 12 per cent, while lower earners might not be able to.



But he did not support allowing people to opt out of the system altogether as this would create a pension burden later.

A debate about whether to push ahead with legislated increases in the super guarantee to 12 per cent by mid-2025 has erupted in an environment of low wages growth.

The Grattan Institute says a majority of people will have a comfortable retirement without any further increases in the super guarantee beyond 9.5 per cent.

Several Coalition backbenchers have suggested that super be made optional for low-income earners because they need higher wages now.

Mr Frawley said the compulsory superannuation system, first established more than 25 years ago, "works just fine" and the government was looking to pull another lever to try to solve the wages growth problem.

"Where people lose confidence in the superannuation sector is the continuation of tinkering and changing," he said.

Advertisement

"If we had wages growth, we wouldn’t be having this conversation. That seems to be the issue."

Wage growth in Australia has slowed significantly over the past five years. The wage price index grew at an annual average of 2.2 per cent in the five years to December 2018, compared with an average annual growth of 3.3 per cent in the previous five years to December 2013.

'Easy option'

Mr Frawley warned that given the outlook for lower returns, the government should not choose the "easy option of taking away savings, which will come back to bite them in the future".

"I don’t know what the answer is to generate wages growth, but it feels like they are trying to pull another lever to try to solve the wages growth problem," he said.

"They have targeted the low end, and they are precisely the people we need to try to help to create savings for in the future. People are aspirational. People want to live nicely in retirement. What are you doing by allowing people the ability not to save is just increasing the pension burden down the road."

The retirement income review will be headed by former Treasury official Mike Callaghan, and Future Fund director Carolyn Kay and Monash University professorial fellow Deborah Ralston will also be on the panel.

The panel will provide a final report to the government by June 2020.
description: Damien Frawley says the rate at which compulsory superannuation is paid should be flexible, possibly ranging from 7.5 per cent at the lower end to 12 per cent at the top.
